Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body, Part Two
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, following the body.
He contemplates the closed sinew worm. He sees with his heard wisdom or with the divine eye:

The closed sinew worm either moves through the coarse sinews or the fine sinews. If the worm's movement is felt, the sinews ache. If the movement is not felt, the sinews do not ache. All the bones and flesh become emaciated, and the sinews ache.
If the worm becomes angry, the person cannot eat.
If it resides in the sinews and drinks the person's blood, it causes weakness. If it eats the person's flesh, it causes emaciation.
Having contemplated the sinew-biting worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body, following the body.
He contemplates with heard wisdom or with the divine eye the moving-veins worm:
This worm moves through all the veins. Its body is extremely fine, and its movement is unobstructed.
If the worms reside in the human food vessels, they will cause illness and make the body dry, with no desire to eat or drink.
If the worms reside in the water vessels, they will cause illness and make the mouth dry;
If they are in the sweat vessels, they will make all the pores of the body sweatless;
If they are in the urine vessels, they will cause stranguary, or damage the essence, or cause painful feelings.
If the worms are angry and move in the lower door, they will cause constipation and obstruction of the bowels, with suffering and near death.
Having contemplated the moving worms, one should know the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally, following the body and observing.
He contemplates the skin-eating worms. With his heard-acquired wisdom or the divine eye, he sees:

Due to excessive food, the skin-eating worms become angry and can cause people's facial complexion to become ugly, or to develop bad blisters, or to be itchy, or red, or yellow, or to burst, or to cause their beard and nails to fall out, to cause people to have bad illnesses, or for their skin to break down or their flesh to rot.
Having contemplated the skin-eating worms, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
He contemplates the fat-biting worms. He sees with his wisdom from hearing or with the divine eye:

The moving fat worms live in the body's fat vessels. If one's food is excessive or one sleeps too much, these worms become angry, causing indigestion, or causing scabies or bad swellings, or causing hair root abscesses, or goiters, or varicose veins, or tuberculosis, or body odor, or sweating when eating.
Having contemplated the moving fat worms in this way, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
He contemplates the harmony-gathering worm in his body, wondering what work it does, whether it causes illness or well-being.
He sees with his wisdom of hearing or with the divine eye that the harmony-gathering worm gathers two kinds of bodies:
First, the conscious body;
Second, the unconscious body.
Skin, flesh, bones, blood, fat, marrow, essence, and so forth are called the conscious body;
Hair, body hair, nails, teeth, and so forth are called the unconscious body.
These are called the two bodies gathered in harmony.

Due to excessive food, the worm loses strength, and the person also loses strength, unable to move quickly back and forth, sleeping sluggishly or feeling thirsty, with skin, flesh, bones, blood, marrow, and essence diminishing.
Having contemplated the harmony-gathering worm, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
He contemplates with his wisdom of hearing or with the divine eye:

The foul-smelling worm lives in the flesh, in feces and urine. Due to excessive food, the worm becomes angry. The flesh, feces, urine, snot, and saliva all become foul-smelling. The rotten pus in the nose or the rotten foul smell of tears follows the worm's movements, all becoming filthy and foul-smelling, whether it is clothing, bedding, or food.

Living in the teeth, due to the worm's foul smell, the food also follows and becomes foul-smelling. The clothing and bedding all become foul-smelling. There is much foul-smelling white plaque on the tongue, and the body's impurities also become foul-smelling.
Having contemplated the foul-smelling worm, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

The moisture-moving worm moves in the back of the flesh. Knowing that the food has been digested, it enters the three holes of the waist, takes the person's feces and impurities, turns the liquid into urine, and the residue into feces, causing it to enter the lower door.
Having contemplated the moisture worm, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
Observing ten kinds of worms that move through the sense faculties, all human bodies are born from them.
What are the ten?
First, called the sliminess worm;
second, called the exhaustion worm;
third, called the sprout flower worm;
fourth, called the great flattery worm;
fifth, called the black worm;
sixth, called the great eating worm;ğŸ”½seventh, called the warm-moving worm;
eighth, called the heat-making worm;
ninth, called the fire worm;
tenth, called the great fire worm.
These worms reside in the bile.
What are the worms that cause illness or well-being for humans?
He sees with his heard-based wisdom or with the divine eye:
If a person overeats, the worms become angry, eat the person's eye muscles, causing the eyes to itch and produce a lot of tears.
If these tiny worms move in the eyes, the eyes become very sick or may be destroyed.
If they enter the essence, white cataracts form in the eyes.
The worm is red in color and causes eye diseases. If the worm is not angry, then there are no such diseases.
Having observed the worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
He sees with his wisdom of hearing or with the divine eye:
The worm lives in the human body, moving in the shadows, unobstructed in all parts of the body, covered by the body's bile.
If the worm enters the bones, it causes the whole body to become hot;
If it moves in the flesh, it causes constant heat day and night, with hot hands and feet;
If it enters the skin, it causes the body to sweat.
Having observed the worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
He sees with his wisdom of hearing or with the divine eye:
The flower-sprout worm moves and resides in the shadows, with sharp spurs and short legs, its body like a hidden fire, not wanting to eat or drink.

If the food is excessive, the worms move to other places. Wherever they go, there will be great heat and rotting. The body's blood increases, and the body becomes greatly heated, like smoke rising. The skin of the body breaks down, like a fire burning a wound.
If the worms move in the right direction, then there will be no such illness.
Having contemplated the worms in the sprouts and flowers, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in contemplation.
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
The great flattery worm lives in the body, moving in the bile. It may be at ease or uneasy.
Due to excessive food, the worm becomes angry. From head to toe, it moves without obstruction, causing all the hot blood in the body to produce hot sores.
Whether it is blood or bile, it flows out from the mouth or ears, either causing death or near-death, or the body becomes blue-yellow, with a fever and a bitter mouth.
If the worm is not angry, then there will be no such illness.
Having contemplated the great flattery worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
He sees with his hearing-acquired wisdom or with the divine eye that the black worm lives inside the body, moving in the yellow shadows, sometimes at ease and sometimes not.

Due to excessive food, the worm becomes angry, causing people's faces to become disfigured, with many moles, either black, yellow, or red, causing the body to smell, or causing the eyes to twitch, or sores to appear in the mouth, or sores to appear in the anus and urethra.
If the worm is not angry, then there will be no such illnesses.
Having contemplated the black worm, he understands the body as it truly is.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation. He sees with his hearing-acquired wisdom or with the divine eye that the large food worm lives in the body, sometimes bringing peace and sometimes causing illness?
He sees with his hearing-acquired wisdom or with the divine eye:

Due to excessive food, the great eater worm becomes angry and resides in the gall bladder. As it eats, it digests, and due to the great strength of the body, the eyes, ears, nose, and tongue in all parts of the body are all diminished in their respective realms, and what is seen is not clear.
Due to excessive food, the faculties do not properly perceive.
If the worm is not angry, then there is no such illness.
Having contemplated the great eater worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in contemplation.
He sees with his hearing or with the divine eye the warm-moving worm, which always loves warm food and hates cold food.
How does this worm cause illness in humans?
How does it bring peace and comfort?
He sees with his hearing or with the divine eye:

If I eat cold food or drink cold beverages, or if I eat or taste something cold, the worm becomes angry, causing excessive salivation, heaviness, numbness, sleepiness, mental dullness, body aches, or excessive mucus or throat ailments.
If the worm is not angry, these illnesses will not occur.
Having observed the warm-natured worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in observation.
He sees with his hearing wisdom or the divine eye that the hot worm resides within the body, moving in the shadows, causing what kinds of illnesses?
How does it bring about peace and well-being?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or the divine eye:
The hot worm resides in the human body. If one eats heavy food, due to excessive eating, the impurities of the illness increase, obstructing the inhalation and exhalation of breath.
Due to excessive food, it causes the body to become coarse and large, or the throat to become blocked, causing feces and urine to all become white, not liking cold, and not liking warm food.
Having observed the hot worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the heavenly eye:
The fire-eating worm lives inside the body, moving in the semen. When this worm is cold, it becomes joyful, and when hot, it becomes weak.
Because of being joyful when cold, a person then thinks of food;
When hot, the fire increases, and one does not want to eat or drink.
In the cold of winter, the semen is then cool, and when hot, the semen is emitted. Thus, the fire-eating worm hates fire like this.
Having observed the fire-eating worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
He sees the great fire worm. How does this worm cause a person to become ill or to be at ease?
With heard-wisdom or the divine eye, he sees the great fire worm:

If a person eats what is uncomfortable by nature, the worm becomes angry and eats the worms in the body. Because of this excess, it causes people to have stomach pain, leg pain, hand pain, or pain wherever the worm is eaten.
If the worm is not angry, then there will be none of the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having observed the yellow shadow worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body following the body.
With heard-wisdom or the divine eye, he observes that there are ten kinds of worms in the bones. What are the ten?
The first is called the bone-licking worm;
the second is called the bone-biting worm;
the third is called the joint-cutting worm;
the fourth is called the red-mouthed stinking worm;
the fifth is called the rotten worm;
the sixth is called the red-mouthed worm;
the seventh is called the tou-tou-mo worm;
the eighth is called the skin-eating worm;
the ninth is called the wind-knife worm;
tenth, named the knife-mouth worm.
How do these bone worms cause illness?
How do they bring about well-being?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

The bone-licking worm lives outside the bones, in places with many bones, such as the thigh bones, leg bones, arm bones, and spine bones. It moves in the blood vessels, and due to excessive food, the worm becomes angry, causing bone pain or bone movement, and making one's complexion bad.
If the worm eats the flesh near the bones, it causes severe bone pain. If the worm is not angry, then there will be no such illnesses as mentioned above.
Having contemplated the bone worms, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body.
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

The bone-biting worm lives throughout the body's bones. If the worm bites the bones, the great elements dry up and diminish, causing diarrhea, indigestion, pain in the ribs, nasal congestion, vomiting, and loss of appetite for food and drink.
If the worm does not bite the bones, one will not have such illnesses.
Having observed the bone-biting worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body following the body.
He sees with his heard-based wisdom or the divine eye the joint-cutting worm:

Due to excessive food, the worm becomes angry, causing headaches, heart pain, or feeling empty and desolate in crowded places such as cities, towns, and villages. The nose is congested and the mind is troubled. Due to the pain and distress, one's mind takes no delight in pleasant forms, sounds, smells, tastes, or tactile objects.
If the joint-cutting worm is well-behaved and not angry, one will not have the aforementioned illnesses.
Having observed the joint-cutting worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, in accordance with reality.
He sees with his hearing or divine eye that the stinking worm lives in the body, sometimes causing illness and sometimes bringing peace.
He sees with his hearing or divine eye that this stinking worm:

Due to excessive food, the worm becomes angry, causing the body to feel heavy and hot, or giving rise to red and black erysipelas, excessive sweating, and an inability to sleep, which then develops into leprosy, with all parts of the body becoming putrid and stinking.
If the worm is not angry, then there will be no such illnesses as mentioned above.
Having contemplated the stinking worm, he understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, in accordance with reality.
He sees with his hearing or divine eye that the rotten bone worm lives inside the body, sometimes causing illness and sometimes bringing peace.
He sees with his hearing or divine eye that the rotten bone worm:
Due to excessive food, the worms become angry, causing wounds for one, two, or even many years, or when young, although healed, they still erupt in old age.
Thus, the putrid worms erupt after a long time, causing the bones to rot and decay, and red sores appear on the body, like the foul-smelling and disgusting udumbara fruit.
The sores are very itchy, with much pus and blood flowing from the sores, attracting flies and mosquitoes to bite.
If the putrid bone worms are docile and not angry, then there will be no illness as described above.
Having contemplated the putrid bone worms, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
He sees with his hearing-wisdom or the heavenly eye that the red-mouthed worm lives in the body's bones, causing what kind of illness?
How does it bring peace and comfort?
He sees with his hearing-wisdom or the heavenly eye that the red-mouthed worm:
If the food is excessive, the worms become angry. Their red color is more intense than the color of fire, causing people's bodies to sweat day and night, resulting in blood deficiency diseases.
If the red-mouthed worms are well-behaved and not angry, then there will be no illnesses as described above.
Having observed the red-mouthed worms, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
He sees with his hearing wisdom or the divine eye that the tou-tou-mo worm lives in the bones and moves in the bones. How does this worm cause people to become ill?
How does it bring peace and comfort?
He sees with his hearing wisdom or the divine eye that the tou-tou-mo worm:
Because of excessive food, the worms become angry and can cause sores to appear all over the body.

If the worms move, they cause one to frequently yawn, the heart to move restlessly, or to feel as if one has lost one's body or the body moves and shakes, unable to sleep, the itching of the body is like the movement of worms, the eyes are unclear, one gets a cold or fever, or the body swells.
If the toutouma worms are not angry, then there are no illnesses as described above.
Having contemplated the toutouma worms, one correctly understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that the skin-eating worm dwells in the body, sometimes causing illness and sometimes bringing peace.
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that the skin-eating worm:
Because of excessive food, the worm becomes angry, causing sores on the lips, eyes, and both sides of the ribs.

If it moves in the sinews or bites the sinews, it can cause the person's throat to become dry, or deaf and blocked, with pus coming out of the ears, or it moves crackling on the skull, or premature gray hair, goiter in the throat, sleeping at improper times, or disliking food, not enjoying one place, liking to walk in empty places, the mind often disturbed, speaking recklessly about right and wrong.
Because the worms eat the skin, all parts of the body are cracked, broken, and covered with dust and dirt.
If the worms are not angry, then there will not be the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the skin-eating worms, one should understand the body as it truly is.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body following the body.ğŸ”½He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that the wind-knife worms move in the bones, and because of the worms' anger, there may be illness or well-being.
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye that the wind-knife worms:

Due to excessive food, the worms become angry, like a snake bite, with pain and poison difficult to endure, namely the top of the head, throat, heart, bladder, and the places of urination and defecation, and also like needles piercing the nails.
Because the worms bite, the nose loses its sense of smell, the tongue does not know taste, the eyes twitch, and one does not remember food and drink.
Because the worms are angry, they harm the body together with the bone-moving worms, and because of the many pains, one does not sleep day or night.
If the worms are not angry, then there will be no illness as described above.
Having contemplated the wind-knife worms, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in contemplation.
He sees with his hearing or with the divine eye that the mouth-knife worm lives in the body, which may cause illness or well-being.
He sees with his hearing or with the divine eye:

The knife-mouth worm begins in the mother's womb. When the child is first born, this worm is also first born. Because of the power of the Dharma, it drinks the mother's milk when first leaving the womb, and at that time this worm eats all the other worms, and later it eats miscellaneous things.
For this reason, the other worms are born again.
Having contemplated the knife-mouth worm, one should know the body as it truly is.
These ten kinds of worms move in the bones. Contemplate them as they truly are.

Having contemplated them as they truly are, the eyes are free from the defilements of dust, free from the faults of ordinary people, the mind gives rise to disgust, is free from 'I' and 'mine', free from doubt and pure, free from wrong views, and knows the body as it truly is up to nirvana.
Furthermore, a practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body.
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see ten kinds of worms moving in feces. What are the ten?
The first is called the born worm;
the second is called the needle-mouth worm;
the third is called the white-joint worm;
the fourth is called the legless worm;
fifth, the scattered juice worms;
sixth, the three-burned worms;
seventh, the intestine-bursting worms;
eighth, the obstruction worms;
ninth, the good-colored worms;
tenth, the foul-smelling wound worms.
Their color is disgusting, dwelling in feces and filth, causing what kind of illness?
How is it peaceful and secure?
He sees with his hearing or with the divine eye:
The worms that live in feces and filth, if the worms are burning hot, my body is also hot.
If the worms have a cold illness, I also have a cold illness, with diarrhea and white pus, causing the body to deteriorate and the complexion to be pale.
If these worms that are born are obedient and not angry, then there will be no illness as described above.
Having observed the worms that are born, one accurately understands the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
He sees with his hearing or with the divine eye:

The needle-mouth worm moves in the feces, its body is long and large, it moves from the mature intestines to theç”Ÿè—, and none of the worms can stop it. It then moves from theç”Ÿè— up to the throat, and saliva and vomit come out together, either causing heart pain or making it uncomfortable.
Because the fire is weak, it comes out together with the feces, and one dies in an instant.
Having observed the needle-mouth worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye:

The white joint worm moves in the feces. Its body is short and white, with many worms connected together. It is cold and very smelly, destroys human strength, and comes out together with the feces, attracting a swarm of flies.
One who has this illness has even more feces and does not think of eating or drinking.
Having observed the white joint worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
With heard-knowledge or the divine eye, he sees the legless worm dwelling in the body. How does this worm cause illness for people?
How does it bring peace and well-being?
With heard-knowledge or the divine eye, he sees the legless worm:

Due to excessive food, the worm becomes angry, blowing on all the wind-qi to block the large and small intestines, or blocking the stomach, unable to vomit or sneeze, unable to yawn, exhausted and uneasy, unable to sleep, intolerant of hunger and thirst.
Because of the worm's anger, many illnesses arise.
Having contemplated the legless worm, he knows the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.

With his heard-transmitting wisdom or the heavenly eye, he sees the juice-scattering worm living in the body. For the sake of digesting food, it scatters the juices, flowing with the juices throughout the body, reaching the feet, and from the feet to the top of the head, the juices flow everywhere, so people say it is a good complexion;
if the juices do not flow, the complexion becomes ugly.
Having observed the juice-scattering worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body following the body.
With his heard-transmitting wisdom or the heavenly eye, he sees:
The three-burn worm lives in the body. If I have a fever, the worm increases in filth, the internal organs are uneasy, and the fire element becomes agitated.
Because of the fever, the worm also has a fever, running all over the body, and burns itself with heat.
Because of the worm's anger, the channels of taste become dry, causing thirst and headaches.
Having observed the three-burn worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, in accordance with reality.
He sees with his hearing or with the divine eye the intestine-breaking worm living in the body. How does this worm cause illness?
How does it bring peace?

He sees with his hearing or with the divine eye that if a person eats too much food and drink, the worms oppress it, the worms then become angry, bite the person's intestines, causing either heart distension, wind distension, heat distension, or cold distension, and one obtains such various kinds of suffering.
This intestine-breaking worm injures a person's intestines. If the worm is well-behaved, then there will be no illness as described above.
Having contemplated the intestine-breaking worm, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, in accordance with reality.
He sees with his hearing or with the divine eye the obstruction worm living in the body. How does this worm cause illness for a person?
How does it bring peace?
They see with their wisdom of hearing or with the divine eye:

The occluding worm moves in the feces. If I eat or drink, the worm also eats. After eating, it occludes. Due to excessive food, it injures the flowing vessels and injures the fire element. The eaten food causes intestinal distension, intestinal twisting, and intestinal torsion, and sometimes causes heart pain and intestinal pain for people.
Having observed the occluding worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner observes the body internally, following the body.
They see with their wisdom of hearing or with the divine eye the good-colored worm dwelling in the body. How does this worm cause illness?
How is it peaceful?
They see with their wisdom of hearing or with the divine eye:

When I eat, whether I eat good meat or bad meat or heavy food, the worm in the body creates peace. It takes flavor in the mouth and runs all over the body, causing no illness or distress, increasing strength, eliminating various illnesses, and dwells in the body.
Due to its merit, the worm has great strength, and the person has complexion and sufficient energy.
If the worm is weak, the person is also emaciated, with a haggard complexion.
Having observed the good-colored worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, following the body in observation.
He uses his heard wisdom or the divine eye to see the lower door sores worm dwelling in the body, thinking: 'How does it cause me illness?
How does it bring me peace?'
He uses his heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:
The lower door sores worm, due to food incompatibilities, becomes angry and produces various sores, either wet sores or dry sores, either front sores or back sores, or hot sores.

If the worm becomes angry and blocks the anus, the channels carrying feces, the channels carrying blood, or the channels carrying juices, or if there is insufficient digestive heat to digest food and drink,
due to insufficient digestive heat, sores appear in the anus.
If the worms are angry, they cause various illnesses. If the worms are not angry, then there will be no illnesses as described above.
Having contemplated the worms in the wounds of the impure body, one should know the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
He sees with his heard-based wisdom or with the divine eye that there are ten kinds of worms that move in the marrow and move in the semen. What are the ten?
The first is called the hair worm;
the second is called the black-mouthed worm;
the third is called the powerless worm;
the fourth is called the great pain worm;
the fifth is called the distressed worm;
the sixth is called the fire-colored worm;
the seventh is called the downward-flowing worm;
the eighth is called the body-root-producing worm;
the ninth is called the memory worm;
the tenth is called the joyful worm.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
He sees with his heard-based wisdom or with the divine eye:

There is a worm called hair worm, whose body parts all grow hair. If this worm becomes angry, it injures the marrow. After causing harm, it eats human marrow, causing leprosy, an ugly complexion, pain in the bones and marrow, and loss of strength.
If the hair worm is docile and does not become angry, then there will be no illnesses as described above.
Having contemplated the hair worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
He sees with his wisdom from hearing or with the divine eye:

The black-mouthed worm resides in the marrow, moving throughout the entire body without obstruction. If the worm becomes angry, it can melt the marrow. Because it injures the marrow, it causes people to have an ugly complexion, a hunched back, a stooped body, difficulty walking, and to walk with a cane. The complexion is haggard and the body shakes.
If the black-mouthed worm is docile and not angry, then there will be no illnesses as described above.
Having observed the black-mouthed worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye:
The weak worm lives in the body. This worm eats the marrow. If the marrow is insufficient, the worm will be weak. Because the worm is weak, the person will also be weak.
There are other worms that also eat human marrow. They are oppressed by stronger worms, and the person will suffer.
Having observed the weak worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, observing the body.
He sees with his hearing wisdom or with the divine eye:

The great pain worm wanders in the marrow, flowing and constantly moving, pervading all the body's elements. This worm can cause various illnesses, and pus and fluid flow out, pervading the sense faculties, and one cannot sleep.
Having observed the great pain worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, in accordance with reality.
He sees with his heard-based wisdom or the divine eye:
The fainting worm lives in the body, moving in the subtle heart blood vessels, obstructing the vessels.

Because of obstructing the vessels, one gets a heart disease, feels faint and wants to vomit, has a bad complexion, does not want to eat or drink, or has a fever and heart pain like being cut by a knife.
When seeing external worms, one feels faint and wants to vomit.
Having contemplated the fainting worm, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, in accordance with reality.
He sees with his heard-based wisdom or the divine eye:
There are worms called downward flow, moving in the semen vessels. If one eats good food or arousing food, it causes the semen to increase. Such worms lead the semen out in the urine vessels.
Having contemplated the downward flow worms, one understands the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, in accordance with reality.
He sees with his heard-wisdom or with the divine eye:

The arising-organ worm lives in the bladder. If the bladder is full of urine, the worm is delighted. Having been delighted, due to the condition of urine, it causes the arising of the sexual organ. This is the door of skillful observation for all foolish ordinary beings.
Having contemplated the arising-organ worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the body internally, in accordance with reality.
He sees with his heard-wisdom or with the divine eye: What kind of illness does the memory-joy worm cause?
How does it bring peace?
If the worm is delighted and powerful, it causes one to see many dreams, good or bad. Due to the fault of the worm and because it moves through the heart vessels, one dreams of various signs.
Having contemplated the memory worm, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Thus, the practitioner-monk who practices in the villages of the NÄrada brahmins and elders, having contemplated in this way, contemplates the body as it truly is.
What in this body is permanent, unmoving, and indestructible?
What is happiness?
What is self?
What is purity?
What can be relied upon?
Through heard-wisdom or the divine eye, he sees:
In this body, whether coarse or fine, there is not a single dharma that is permanent, unmoving, indestructible, happy, pure, or self that can be relied upon.
It is like a person seeking the darkness in the middle of the day, whether coarse or fine, all cannot be found;
The body is also like this, if there is seeking for its permanence, happiness, self, and purity, it also cannot be found. This is called the practitioner's internal body contemplation of the body.

When contemplating in this way, one distances oneself from the realm of Mara, approaches the path of nirvana, and love cannot disturb, nor can the other afflictions create obstacles. This is called internal body contemplation of the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner internally contemplates the body in the body.
What kinds of winds reside in the body, and what work do they do when they are either in balance or out of balance?
By means of heard-wisdom or the divine eye, he sees the mind-turning wind residing in the body.
How does the mind wind move the body?
By means of heard-wisdom or the divine eye, he sees:

The mind-turning wind, due to the balance of the wind, can move the body, either walking or staying, bending or raising, or doing various things. Due to the power of the wind, it can be either comfortable or dangerous.
Having contemplated the mind-turning wind, he knows the body as it truly is. This is called the internal body contemplation of the body.
Furthermore, the practitioner internally contemplates the body.
What kinds of winds reside in the body, and what work do they do when they are either in balance or out of balance?
By means of heard-wisdom or the divine eye, he sees the nail-wind residing in the body. If it is not in harmony, what does it do?

The nails on the hands and feet grow due to the condition of wind, even until old age, this is called observing the wind in the nails.

Having observed the wind under the feet, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kinds of winds abide in the body, and what activities do they perform when in balance or out of balance?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see the unaware wind abiding in the body, and what it does when in balance or out of balance.
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see:

The unaware wind abides in the skin, causing the bones to tingle. Due to the power of the wind, the skin around the bones is like ants crawling. If one presses the wound with the hand, it is like an ant insect.
Having observed the unaware wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kinds of winds abide in the body, and what activities do they perform when in balance or out of balance?
Using their heard-cognition or divine eye, they observe that there is a wind in the body called bone-breaker. If it is not well-regulated, what does it do?
Using their heard-cognition or divine eye, they see:

The bone-breaking wind, sometimes during the day or night, whether walking, standing, in a garden or forest, in a temple or dwelling, or when exhausted, breaks the bones, causing pain and preventing sleep, making the hands and feet inconvenient and unable to bend or stretch.
Having observed the bone-breaking wind, they understand the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body following the body.
What kinds of winds create what kinds of activities?
Using their heard-cognition or divine eye, they see that there is a wind in the body called breaker of movement. If it is not well-regulated, what does it do?
Using their heard-cognition or divine eye, they see:
If the breaker of movement wind is not well-regulated, this wind will arise, causing disturbance, making one unable to walk, come and go, or progress.
Having observed and destroyed the wind of action, one should know the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
What kinds of winds abide in the body, whether regulated or unregulated, what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see the breaking ankle wind abiding in the body, what does it do?

If the breaking joint wind encounters cold, it causes pain in the thigh bones throughout the body.
Having contemplated the breaking joint wind, one should know the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates internally the body according to the body.
What kinds of winds abide in the body, whether regulated or unregulated, what kind of activities do they perform?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see the breaking thigh bone wind abiding in the body, if unregulated, what does it do?

If the breaking thigh bone wind is not in harmony, it causes the veins of flowing liquid inside the thighs to be swollen and very strong, causing the legs to bend and stretch, with the two thighs close together, the flesh heavy and swollen.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in observation.
What kinds of winds are there that dwell in the body, whether in harmony or not, and what kind of activities do they perform?

If the thigh-bone wind is not well-regulated, one cannot bend or stretch, cannot walk or come, due to the excess of the disease.

What winds reside in the body, whether well-regulated or not, what work do they do?
Using their heard-based wisdom or the divine eye, they see:
The body-movement-realm wind resides in the body. If it is not well-regulated, what does it do?
Using their heard-based wisdom or the divine eye, they see:

If the body-realm wind is well-regulated and at ease, one will have strength, the breath will come and go, one will be able to digest food, the body will have a complexion, and the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body will all be at ease, and what one eats will be digested.

If it is not well-regulated, the body's complexion becomes coarse and evil, the five faculties become inferior, food and drink are not digested, the complexion is not pleasant, the eyes and other faculties are weak in regard to objects, and one does not give birth to children.

What winds are present in the body, and what actions do they perform when well-regulated or not?

The sinew-drawing wind is present in the body. If it is not well-regulated, what does it do?
He uses heard wisdom or the divine eye to see the sinew-drawing wind:
If the wind is well-regulated, whatever one does, whether sleeping or staying still, all the body's colors are lustrous, and this is the work of the sinew wind.
If it is not well-regulated, one is unable to practice, whether sleeping or staying still, and one is unable to do anything.
Having observed the sinew wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.

What winds are present in the body, and what activities do they perform when in balance or imbalance?

If the going and returning wind is not in harmony, it blocks the body's channels and causes strangury, pain in all parts of the body, abdominal pain, pain in the sense faculties, inability to eat or drink, and depletion of essence and blood, resulting in difficulty conceiving a child.

Having observed the going and returning wind, one should understand the body as it truly is.

What winds are present in the body, and what activities do they perform when in balance or imbalance?

If the joint-agitation wind is balanced, then one will not have the above-mentioned illnesses.
Having contemplated the joint-agitation wind, he knows the body as it truly is.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates the internal body, following the body in contemplation.
What winds reside in my body, balanced or unbalanced, and what activities do they perform?

Always thinking:
